title: 107_s1686
content: The Act titled "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2001" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 contains findings related to the Act. The Federal Government has a significant interest in ensuring adequate and safe healthcare services for patients in healthcare facilities. Research shows that higher nurse staffing levels lead to better patient outcomes, but there are challenges in recruiting and retaining enough nursing staff. Job dissatisfaction and mandatory overtime contribute to nurses leaving the profession. The widespread use of mandatory overtime in healthcare facilities contributes to nurse fatigue, leading to medical errors and compromising patient safety. Limiting mandatory overtime can ensure public safety, quality healthcare services, and aid in nurse retention and recruitment. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Provider Agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. A new subsection is added to prohibit mandatory overtime for nurses, with exceptions outlined. Limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses include prohibiting working in excess of scheduled shifts, 12 hours in a 24-hour period, or 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period, with exceptions during declared states of emergency. During a declared state of emergency, providers of services may be exempt from certain requirements if they are expected to provide exceptional emergency or medical services to the community. Nurses can only be required to work beyond specified limits if the provider has tried to fill staffing needs through other means and the work duration does not exceed certain limits. During a declared state of emergency, nurses can file complaints against providers who violate work requirement provisions. The work duration should not extend past the end of the state of emergency or the provider's direct role in responding to medical needs. During a state of emergency, nurses can report violations by providers to the Secretary, who will investigate and take action if necessary. During a state of emergency, nurses can report violations by providers to the Secretary, who will investigate and take action if necessary. Providers of services must not penalize or discriminate against nurses who refuse to work mandatory overtime or who raise concerns about their employment conditions. If a provider violates these rules, the Secretary can require them to create a plan to address the violation and may impose civil money penalties. Nurses are protected from retaliation for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations. They can report to regulatory agencies or initiate investigations without fear of repercussions. Nurses are protected from retaliation for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations. They can report violations to regulatory agencies without fear of repercussions. Providers of services cannot file complaints against nurses who refuse to work mandatory overtime. Nurses are protected from retaliation for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations. Providers of services cannot file complaints against nurses who refuse to work overtime. Nurses must act in good faith when reporting violations. Each provider of services must post a notice specifying nurses' rights under this section. Each provider of services must post a notice specifying nurses' rights under this section, including the right to file a complaint with the Secretary against violations. Providers must also regularly post nurse schedules in a conspicuous manner. The provider of services must regularly post nurse schedules for the department or unit and make them available to nurses upon request. The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation of this requirement. The Secretary may impose more severe civil money penalties for providers who establish patterns of repeated violations. The names of providers facing penalties will be published on the Department of Health and Human Services website. The Secretary will publish names of providers facing civil money penalties, along with violation details on the Department of Health and Human Services website. Penalties imposed on providers under previous ownership will not be published after a 1-year period from the change in ownership. The subsection allows nurses to work voluntarily beyond specified time periods, defined as mandatory overtime, without facing adverse employment consequences. The curr_chunk defines terms related to a nurse's voluntary work beyond specified time periods, including potential adverse employment consequences. The terms include overtime, nurse (registered or licensed practical), and provider of services (hospital, outpatient department, critical access hospital). The curr_chunk defines a "provider of services" as various healthcare facilities, including hospitals, outpatient departments, and clinics, during a "declared state of emergency" officially designated by the Federal Government or appropriate authority. The curr_chunk further clarifies that a "declared state of emergency" refers to an officially designated emergency by the Federal Government or appropriate state/local authority, excluding labor disputes or understaffing issues. It also defines "standards of safe patient care" as the professional standards for nurses. The curr_chunk states that the amendments regarding "standards of safe patient care" will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to establish safe working hour standards for nurses providing healthcare, considering various factors. A report to Congress is due within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Director may contract with an eligible entity to conduct a study on appropriate standards of maximum work hours. A report to Congress on the study's findings and recommendations is required within 2 years. Additionally, a study on overtime practices for nurses in federally operated medical facilities will be conducted by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Management will conduct a study on overtime practices for nurses in federally operated medical facilities, including acute care hospitals, freestanding clinics, and home health care clinics operated by government departments. A report to Congress is due within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Management will conduct a study on overtime practices for nurses in federally operated medical facilities and submit a report to Congress with recommendations for policy implementation within 6 months of the Act's enactment.
